description: Borrowed from Medieval Latin circumgȳrō; equivalent to circum- +‎ gyrate.

verbs.description: circumgyrate (third-person singular simple present circumgyrates, present participle circumgyrating, simple past and past participle circumgyrated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to move around something; to cause to orbit.
examples: The soul about it self circumgyrates

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To turn in a circle around an axis or fixed point.
(transitive) To cause to turn in a circle around an axis or fixed point.
(intransitive) To make circuits (around an area or space).
examples: […]  every motion of the small fish playing in its [the stream’s] pellucid pools, was as distinctly visible as those of the unfortunate goldfish one sometimes observes pensively circumgyrating in the interior of its enchanted globular ball in the shop-window.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be formed into a bent or curved shape (around something).
examples: […]  it circumgyrates round the stove, and exposes its large surfaces to the air warming space  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form into a bent or curved shape.
